He lives in con- start dread of his double life being exposed, and his fearis considerably increased by the fact that he is financially dependent upon his Athenian wife's income. He has no intention of do- ing this, 'but he has immediate need of just this amount of money. His need involves the secondary plot of the play which is concerned with another love affair, namely that of Chremes’ son Phaedria and Pamphila, a slave girl upon whom her master Dorio had set a price of thirty minae.
